abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. It is widely recognized
            that damages associated with disasters, such as El Nino,
            usually reflect either the disaster itself, or cumulative
            neglect, and deferred maintenance, or weak, ineffective
            operational, and institutional systems, and framework,
            respectively. In Guyana, all three factors were present:
            infrastructure neglect - drainage, irrigation, and potable
            water systems - occurred even before the impact of El Nino;
            likewise, operational sector agencies, aggravated by budget
            constraints, weak capacity, and absence of regulatory
            enforcement, also had cumulative negative impacts. While the
            Government made commendable relief, and reconstruction
            efforts, the lack of resources for appropriate maintenance,
            institutional, and operational support, will hamper the
            facilities provided by this credit, and will remain
            vulnerable to future disasters. Based on the above, lessons
            reinforce that while the Government appropriately recognized
            early on the potential impact of the oncoming drought, and
            took steps in seeking international assistance to dimension
            the impact, with demonstrated commitment, the existing weak
            procurement system, prevailed in delaying what otherwise
            could, and should have helped the contracting process for
            this (shorter than usual) emergency operation. Likewise, a
            slow decision-making process, the lack of uniform civil
            engineering norms, and standards, and weak absorptive
            capacity, and coordination clearly limited the
            implementation pace required for a fast, responsive
            emergency operation.
